dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Tonko (for himself and Mr. Peters) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce

form.official-title: To require the Secretary of Energy to remove carbon dioxide directly from ambient air or seawater, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Federal Carbon Dioxide Removal Leadership Act of 2022.

section.header: Federal requirement to remove carbon dioxide

subsection.text: The Secretary shall, to the extent economically feasible as provided in subsection (d), remove—

paragraph.text: 50,000 net metric tons of carbon dioxide, calculated on a lifecycle basis, for each of fiscal years 2024 through 2025;
500,000 net metric tons of carbon dioxide, calculated on a lifecycle basis, for each of fiscal years 2026 through 2028;
5,000,000 net metric tons of carbon dioxide, calculated on a lifecycle basis, for each of fiscal years 2029 through 2034; and
10,000,000 net metric tons of carbon dioxide, calculated on a lifecycle basis, for fiscal year 2035 and each fiscal year thereafter.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall remove each amount of carbon dioxide required under subsection (a) by not later than 3 years after the beginning of the fiscal year for which such removal is required.

To the extent practicable, at least 20 percent of the net metric tons of carbon dioxide required to be removed for each of fiscal years 2024 through 2034 under subsection (a) shall be removed by small removal projects.

paragraph.text: The removal of carbon dioxide under this section shall be considered economically feasible if such removal can be accomplished or, in the case of a contract, purchased—

subparagraph.text: with respect to such removal carried out for any of fiscal years 2024 through 2025, at a price per metric ton of carbon dioxide of not more than $550;
with respect to such removal carried out for any of fiscal years 2026 through 2028, at a price per metric ton of carbon dioxide of not more than $400;
with respect to such removal carried out for any of fiscal years 2029 through 2031, at a price per metric ton of carbon dioxide of not more than $300;
with respect to such removal carried out for any of fiscal years 2032 through 2034, at a price per metric ton of carbon dioxide of not more than $200; and
with respect to such removal carried out for fiscal year 2035 and each fiscal year thereafter, at a price per metric ton of carbon dioxide of not more than $150.

paragraph.header: Inclusion of monitoring, reporting, and verification costs
paragraph.text: In determining whether the removal of carbon dioxide is considered economically feasible under paragraph (1), the price for such removal shall include any costs associated with the monitoring, reporting, and verification required under subsection (f)(1).

Notwithstanding paragraph (1), the removal of carbon dioxide carried out pursuant to a multi-year contract entered into under subsection (h) shall be considered economically feasible if such removal can be accomplished at the applicable dollar amount for the first fiscal year of the contract, as provided in paragraph (1), through the entire length of such contract.

subsection.text: Funds received pursuant to a contract entered into under subsection (h) shall not be considered Federal assistance or otherwise affect eligibility for any Federal assistance, including tax incentives.

paragraph.text: The Secretary, or an entity the Secretary enters into a contract with under subsection (h), shall monitor, report, and verify the net metric tons of carbon dioxide the Secretary or such entity, as applicable, removed for purposes of this section.

The Secretary shall ensure that any project for the removal of carbon dioxide for which a contract is entered into under subsection (h) shall follow the best available practices, as determined by the Secretary, for monitoring, reporting, and verifying the net metric tons of carbon dioxide removed under the project, including best practices—

subparagraph.text: used by similar carbon dioxide removal projects; and
necessary to ensure safe, effective, and efficient removal of carbon dioxide.

paragraph.text: Carbon dioxide that is removed for the purposes of compliance with any other greenhouse gas emissions management program, including any foreign, Federal, State, local, or private greenhouse gas emissions management program, as determined by the Secretary, may not be considered removed under subsection (a) for purposes of meeting the requirements of such subsection.

subsection.text: In carrying out this section, the Secretary shall give priority to any project for the removal of carbon dioxide that—

paragraph.text: minimizes the amount of greenhouse gas emissions released by carrying out such project;
supports the commercialization of innovative removal technologies;
increases the diversity of commercially available eligible technologies;
provides the greatest potential for domestic job creation;

results in economic development or economic diversification in regions or localities that have historically generated significant economic activity from the production, processing, transportation, or combustion of fossil fuels, including through the use of coal mines, fossil fuel-fired electricity generating units, and petroleum refining facilities;
quantifies and mitigates the effect of removing carbon dioxide on environmental justice, the environment, and public health; and
includes robust public engagement and community benefits.
The Secretary may enter into contracts to meet the requirements of subsection (a).
A contract entered into under this subsection may not be for a term of more than 15 years.

subsection.text: Not later than January 1, 2027, and every 2 years thereafter, the Secretary shall submit to Congress, and release to the public, a report on the progress of carrying out the requirements of this section, which such report shall include—

paragraph.text: the amounts verified under subsection (f)(1);
the total price, and price per metric ton, to remove carbon dioxide for the applicable fiscal year as required under subsection (a);
the methods associated with the monitoring, reporting, and verification required under subsection (f)(1);
an estimate of how removing carbon dioxide under this section affects environmental justice, the environment, and public health; and
information on potential labor impacts and job creation resulting from fulfilling the requirements of subsection (a).

subsection.text: There are authorized to be appropriated such sums as are necessary to carry out this section.

subparagraph.text: The term eligible technology means any equipment, technique, or technology, placed into service after January 1, 2022, that removes carbon dioxide directly from ambient air or seawater, as determined appropriate by the Secretary.
The term eligible technology does not include any equipment, technique, or technology that—

clause.text: removes carbon dioxide which is deliberately released from naturally occurring subsurface springs;
removes carbon dioxide using natural photosynthesis; or
is related to the extraction, refinement, delivery, or use of fossil fuels, including enhanced oil recovery.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding subparagraph (B)(ii), any equipment, technique, or technology that removes carbon dioxide using gasification or pyrolysis of solid, nonhazardous, and cellulosic waste materials may be considered an eligible technology under this section if the Secretary, by rule—

clause.text: determines an entity that carries out a removal project under this section is able to adequately monitor, report, and verify the amount of greenhouse gas emissions, calculated on a lifecycle basis (including direct emissions and significant indirect emissions), associated with such equipment, technique, or technology;

determines an entity that carries out a removal project under this section is able to adequately mitigate the environmental impacts (including impacts on biodiversity, land use, and air and water quality) associated with such equipment, technique, or technology; and
requires an entity carrying out a removal project under this section to—

subclause.text: adequately monitor, report, and verify the amount of greenhouse gas emissions, calculated on a lifecycle basis (including direct emissions and significant indirect emissions), associated with such equipment, technique, or technology; and
adequately mitigate the environmental impacts (including impacts on biodiversity, land use, and air and water quality) associated with such equipment, technique, or technology.

paragraph.text: The term remove means to—

subparagraph.text: capture carbon dioxide using eligible technology; and
permanently store such captured carbon dioxide—

clause.text: in a subsurface geologic formation or in materials, including building materials and mineralized carbon materials; or
using other permanent storage methods, as determined by the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The term Secretary means the Secretary of Energy.

The term small removal project means a project for the removal of carbon dioxide that does not remove more than 5 percent of the net metric tons of carbon dioxide required to be removed for the applicable fiscal year under subsection (a).
